author: potuz
content: Is this so? There's a bunch of "ethereum.org" subpages that explicitly mention polynomial commitments whenever "verkle" is mentioned. The V is for vector (commitment) afaik.

author: bridge-bot
content: <ralexstokes> both concepts are pointing at the same thing here

author: bridge-bot
content: <ralexstokes> a vector comm is a more general idea than a poly comm

author: bridge-bot
content: <ralexstokes> but we are using IPAs for Verkle tries (which are vector comms but you can just write your poly's coeffs as vector elements and get a poly comm)

author: potuz
content: Ah fine, I interpreted <@555483069038198827>'s reply in a different way

author: bridge-bot
content:
<dankrad> The two are very closely related: Every polynomial commitment is (trivially) a vector commitment. Every vector commitment that is also additively linear (i.e. two commitments can be added together and form a new commitment for the elementwise sum) can be turned into a polynomial commitment using IPAs (Inner Product Arguments)

We started out by trying to use KZG as our vector commitment, but it turned out simpler Pedersen commitments are a lot faster and more suitable to our usecase
